Eluding Secure Aggregation in Federated Learning
via Model Inconsistency

Dario Pasquini dario.pasquini@epfl.ch SPRING Lab, EPFLLausanneSwitzerland ,  Danilo Francati dfrancati@cs.au.dk Aarhus UniversityAarhusDenmark  and  Giuseppe Ateniese ateniese@gmu.edu George Mason UniversityFairfax, VirginiaUSA
Abstract.

Secure aggregation is a cryptographic protocol that securely computes the aggregation of its inputs. It is pivotal in keeping model updates private in federated learning. Indeed, the use of secure aggregation prevents the server from learning the value and the source of the individual model updates provided by the users, hampering inference and data attribution attacks.

In this work, we show that a malicious server can easily elude secure aggregation as if the latter were not in place. We devise two different attacks capable of inferring information on individual private training datasets, independently of the number of users participating in the secure aggregation. This makes them concrete threats in large-scale, real-world federated learning applications.

The attacks are generic and equally effective regardless of the secure aggregation protocol used. They exploit a vulnerability of the federated learning protocol caused by incorrect usage of secure aggregation and lack of parameter validation. Our work demonstrates that current implementations of federated learning with secure aggregation offer only a “false sense of security”.

Federated Learning, Secure Aggregation, Model Inconsistency
††copyright: none††conference: ACM Conference on Computer and Communications Security; Due 15 May 2019; London, TBD††journalyear: 2019

1. Introduction

Deep learning is evolving rapidly but often at the expense of privacy and security. Neural networks may misbehave, hide backdoors, or be reverse-engineered to reveal sensitive information about the training datasets (Ateniese et al., 2015; Shokri et al., 2017; Fredrikson et al., 2015). Data holders are thus reluctant to provide and share their datasets unless some level of protection is in place.

Cryptographic primitives, such as multi-party computation (MPC) and fully homomorphic encryption (FHE), offer only a partial solution to this problem: They enable learning while protecting sensitive information but at the expense of efficiency and scalability. Even state-of-the-art implementations of these primitives are highly inefficient and add a significant overhead to the learning process, making them unusable and inapplicable in practice.

Accordingly, researchers have looked at alternative solutions that rely on decentralization, where data remain local with the participants while the neural network evolves during the distributed learning process. Along this line of research, federated learning (FL) (Konečný et al., 2016, 2017; Bonawitz et al., 2019), along with its main implementations federated stochastic gradient descent (FedSGD) and federated averaging (FedAVG), has been proposed. At a high level, FL allows a set of users to train a shared neural network without outsourcing their local datasets. To this end, they are only required to locally train the neural network and send model updates (e.g., gradients, model parameters) to a central server. The updates will be aggregated by the server, completing a round of the training. The informal security guarantee offered by FL is that sharing the (possibly scrambled (Abadi et al., 2016)) updates does not leak any information about the actual training instances used by the users. Unfortunately, it has been shown that an adversary can invert an individual model update of a target user in order to leak a large amount of information about its dataset (Hitaj et al., 2017; Nasr et al., 2019; Zhu et al., 2019; Melis et al., 2019).

For this reason, Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017) have proposed to combine secure aggregation (SA) protocols with FL as a first step to increase the security of FL, preventing the server from accessing individual model updates. Informally, SA is a specialized MPC protocol that allows a set of users to compute the sum of their private inputs securely. The security guarantee is the same as standard MPC protocols, i.e., nothing is leaked about the inputs except what can be inferred from the output (the sum of the values).

SA is believed to be one of the most robust defenses against gradient inversion and related inference attacks (Huang et al., 2021). In particular, the application of SA in FL has two main objectives: (1) “Privacy by aggregation”: Aggregating together a suitable number of model updates smooths out the information carried out by individual contributions. In turn, this makes it unfeasible to assert or recover meaningful information on individual training instances that produced the aggregated value. (2) “Privacy by shuffling”: SA “hides” the source of the aggregated information; even if sensitive data is recovered from the aggregated model updates, this cannot be attributed to the user (the individual model update) who provided it. Thus, although the privacy of the set of users may be violated, the privacy of individuals is preserved.

Our work shows that a motivated and malicious server can easily violate both of these fundamental properties of current SA defenses. This vulnerability emerges from the federated learning protocol, not the SA protocol; it is caused by incorrect usage of the SA protocol. For example, even if we abstract the SA protocol with an ideal aggregation functionality, the protocol is still exploitable. In this case, the failure to validate SA inputs by the user is one of the protocol’s weaknesses, and we are not targeting a specific implementation of SA. The main intuition is that model updates (i.e., the inputs of SA) are under the indirect control of the malicious server since model updates are computed starting from the parameters sent by the server. A malicious server can leverage this control to tamper with the updates (that are the inputs of SA) so that their aggregation will leak information about the update of a target user.

In order to achieve this, the server exploits a new attack vector that we call model inconsistency. Here, the server distributes different views of the same model to different users within the same round. In this work, we show that model inconsistency can introduce new vulnerabilities in FL algorithms. The intuition is that a malicious server, providing different parameters to different users, can exploit behavioral differences in the model updates provided by the different models to infer information on users’ datasets, even when those model updates are securely aggregated before reaching the server.

To make this inherent vulnerability evident, we implement two attacks that give a representative view of the threat induced by the model inconsistency attack vector. Eventually, these attacks demonstrate how a malicious server can nullify the security offered by current SA-based defenses proposed for FL. That is: (1) individual model updates can be perfectly recovered from the final aggregated value, independently of the number of users participating in the aggregation, and, (2) the source of the recovered data can be attributed to individuals in the pool of active users.

Finally, we introduce multiple strategies for preventing the vulnerability that was brought up. The proposed solutions seamlessly integrate with current state-of-the-art SA protocols without impacting performance or utility.

1.1. Contributions

Our contributions can be summarized as follows:

Model inconsistency

We demonstrate that FL incorrectly leverages SA (Bonawitz et al., 2017), and as a result, it is as secure as the original FL protocol (without SA). We prove this by introducing a new adversarial strategy, named model inconsistency, that leverages the following two observations: (i)𝑖(i) in each protocol round, the SA’s input of user ui∈𝒰subscript𝑢𝑖𝒰u_{i}\in\mathcal{U} is its model update Δ𝒟iΘsubscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝑖\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}} and, (i​i)𝑖𝑖(ii) the value of Δ𝒟iΘsubscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝑖\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}} of each ui∈𝒰subscript𝑢𝑖𝒰u_{i}\in\mathcal{U} depends on the parameters ΘΘ\Theta sent by the server S𝑆S (i.e., different parameters produce different model updates). The combination of the above two observations implies that S𝑆S could act maliciously and craft different parameters for different users in order to tamper with the inputs of SA. As our two attacks will demonstrate, at a different scale, S𝑆S can exclude from the aggregation the updates of some non-target users 𝒰∖{u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍}𝒰subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{U}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\}, forcing the SA to leak part of the model update Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍ΘsubscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of the target u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}.

Gradient suppression attack

In Section 5, we present a first attack, named gradient suppression. It shows that a malicious server can force the local training of the deep model fΘ~subscript𝑓~Θf_{\widetilde{\Theta}} executed by uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} to unconditionally produce a zeroed gradient Δ𝒟iΘ~=[0]subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscript𝒟𝑖delimited-[]0\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu[0]. By combining both gradient suppression and model inconsistency, the server S𝑆S can send the honest parameters ΘΘ\Theta to the target user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} and the malicious parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} to the remaining non-target ones 𝒰∖{u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍}𝒰subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{U}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\}. In turn, this will leak the honest u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}’s gradient Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍ΘsubscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} even if SA is in place. This is because SA will sum up the zeroed gradients of 𝒰∖{u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍}𝒰subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{U}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\} and the honest gradient of u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. The output will be equal to the gradient Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍ΘsubscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of the latter user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. This is the first practical attack that demonstrates that a malicious server can completely nullify SA. More importantly, the attack does not require auxiliary information on the targets, e.g., the distribution of users’ datasets, or unrealistic architecture alterations.

Canary-gradient attack

We extend the first attack and devise a second approach called canary-gradient. Here, we show that a malicious server S𝑆S can modify the target’s model to induce specific behavior in the derivative of a tiny subset ξ𝜉\xi of its parameters (e.g., two out of millions of parameters). In particular, S𝑆S can forge malicious parameters that force the model to produce non-zero gradients for ξ𝜉\xi only when a specific adversarially-chosen property is present in the input batch used to compute the update. Then, the server can preserve the target’s gradient for ξ𝜉\xi in the final aggregated value by forcing the non-target users to unconditionally produce zero gradients only for the parameters ξ𝜉\xi. This allows S𝑆S to recover the target’s gradient for ξ𝜉\xi in “plaintext” and ascertain the presence of the queried property in the user’s private data (e.g., membership inference). Eventually, this demonstrates that a malicious server can cast extremely effective property inference attacks on individual users under SA, while ensuring the stealthiness of the attack.

The (in)correct usage of SA in FL

In cryptographic terms, SA protocols are specialized multi-party computation (MPC) protocols that implement the ideal functionality f𝗌𝖺​(v1,…,vn)=∑ui∈𝒰vi=vsuperscript𝑓𝗌𝖺subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝒰subscript𝑣𝑖𝑣f^{\mathsf{sa}}(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n})=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}v_{i}=v. They are built assuming that the inputs of honest users are untamperable, i.e., an adversary has no control over the input visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} of an honest user ui∈𝒰subscript𝑢𝑖𝒰u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}. This holds in both the semi-honest and malicious security models.

Unfortunately, the above assumption does not hold in FL. As discussed earlier, a malicious server S𝑆S can tamper with the inputs (v1,…,vn)subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}) of the honest users 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}. Unlike other attacks, ours is the first that does not contradict the security of the underlying SA protocol and does not require auxiliary information about user data. Our attacks will succeed regardless of the number of FL protocol users, which is additional evidence that SA and FL cannot protect against adversarial servers.

Preventing model inconsistency.

We discuss ways to help mitigate model inconsistency by integrating consistency checks during the FL protocol. In particular, we show that the two most influential SA protocols of Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017) (CCS’17) and Bell et al. (Bell et al., 2020) (CCS’20) can be modified to incorporate consistency checks without affecting the efficiency of the original FL protocol. This is achieved by linking SA’s masking values (generated by a particular user to hide its input) to the parameters received from the server. By doing it this way, when two or more users receive different parameters, their masks will look random. As a result, the malicious server cannot tell whose input is whose, reducing the attack efficacy.

Finally, we will discuss how DP techniques can be used in conjunction with SA, which remains a suitable solution to prevent a malicious server from breaching users’ privacy. We refer the reader to Section 7 for more details.

To make our results reproducible, we made our code available.111https://github.com/pasquini-dario/EludingSecureAggregation.

2. Related Work

2.1. Federated learning and secure aggregation

The distributed architecture of FL protocol (Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; McMahan et al., 2017) provides a fertile ground for attackers (Hitaj et al., 2017; Melis et al., 2019; Nasr et al., 2019; Fang et al., 2020). This is because a malicious party, mainly the server, has access to sensitive information such as model updates that can be exploited to violate users’ privacy. Accordingly, SA has been proposed by Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017) as a fundamental step to increase the security of FL without modifying the original structure of the protocol. Subsequent works focus on the development of new SA protocols for FL with reduced communication/computation overhead (Bell et al., 2020; Choi et al., 2020; Guo et al., 2020; Kadhe et al., 2020; So et al., 2021b), multiple servers (Beguier and Tramel, 2020), increased robustness against malicious updates (Pillutla et al., 2019; Burkhalter et al., 2021), or with verifiable aggregation (Xu et al., 2019b; Guo et al., 2020).222In FL with verifiable aggregations (Xu et al., 2019b; Guo et al., 2020), users are supposed to verify the integrity of the aggregated model updates and compute the new parameters (if the parameters are updated solely by the server, then the verifiability of aggregated gradients becomes meaningless). This differs from the original FL protocol (Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; McMahan et al., 2017) in which the server updates the model for improved scalability.

Separately, several other works focused on building new protocols (or propose significant modifications of FL, e.g., protocol, architecture, etc.) to train a deep neural network without leaking unnecessary information about the datasets of the users. We refer the reader to Appendix A for more details.

2.2. Gradient Inversion

A core privacy concern in FL is the role of the server. In this direction, it has been shown that, without SA, even a semi-honest server can invert users’ gradients (sent as a model update in a particular round of FL) and compute a close-enough approximation of users’ local training datasets. In a nutshell, by leveraging fΘsubscript𝑓Θf_{\Theta} (where ΘΘ\Theta are the parameters of the current round of FL) and the gradient locally computed by the user u𝑢u using a subset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} of its local data, the server can recover 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} by searching a set of instances 𝒟^^𝒟\widehat{\mathcal{D}} that generates the gradient similar to the one sent by the user. Thanks to the inherent smoothness of the neural network fΘsubscript𝑓Θf_{\Theta}, this searching problem can be defined as a second-order optimization, i.e.,

(1) argmin𝒟^​[d​(∇𝒟^Θ,∇𝒟Θ)⋅α​r​(𝒟^)]subscriptargmin^𝒟delimited-[]⋅𝑑subscriptsuperscript∇Θ^𝒟subscriptsuperscript∇Θ𝒟𝛼𝑟^𝒟\text{argmin}_{\widehat{\mathcal{D}}}[d(\nabla^{\Theta}_{\widehat{\mathcal{D}}},\nabla^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}})\cdot\alpha r(\widehat{\mathcal{D}})]

where 𝒟^^𝒟\widehat{\mathcal{D}} is the candidate solution of the malicious server S𝑆S, d𝑑d is a distance function to measure the discrepancy between the gradient signals ∇𝒟^Θsubscriptsuperscript∇Θ^𝒟\nabla^{\Theta}_{\widehat{\mathcal{D}}} and ∇𝒟Θsubscriptsuperscript∇Θ𝒟\nabla^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}}, r𝑟r is a regularizer defined on the input domain, and α𝛼\alpha is the weight associated to the regularization term in the optimization. In the work of Zhu et al. (Zhu et al., 2019), d𝑑d is set to be the Euclidean distance, and the L-BFGS solver is used to solve the optimization problem. The follow-up work of Geiping et al. (Geiping et al., 2020) improves their approach/results by noting that the gradient signal is scale-invariant and accounts for that in defining the optimization objective in Equation 1. Their work improves the effectiveness of the inversion attack, drastically increasing its applicability on real-world architectures such as ResNets (He et al., 2016) and more realistic batch sizes and a number of FedAVG local iterations. These results have been further improved in the work of Yin et al. (Yin et al., 2021) by relying on additional regularization terms and tailored optimization techniques.

A more recent line of research dispensed with optimization-based approaches to focus on closed-form procedures to recover data from gradients in deep neural networks (Zhu and Blaschko, 2020; Pan et al., 2020). In this vein, a recent work of Fowl et al. (Fowl et al., 2021) (which is concurrent to our work) improves over previous approaches by considering a malicious server that modifies the FL architecture and crafts the network parameters to artificially create a neural layer that retains information on the input batch. In particular, this is a linear layer followed by a ReLU activation whose parameters must be chosen considering the private sets’ CDF for a given property, i.e., the attacker must have some auxiliary information on users’ training datasets. Unfortunately, this extra knowledge may not be acquired in realistic scenarios (when users’ data distributions are unknown) and weakens the applicability of the attack. In addition, the server needs to manipulate the model architecture and place a linear layer at the start of the network to maximize the attack effectiveness. However, this modification is unworkable for typical deep learning applications (e.g., in computer vision).

Lam et al. (Lam et al., 2021) showed that, if SA is enabled, a malicious server S𝑆S can still try to reconstruct individual contributions by observing multiple training rounds of FL. This disaggregation process can be reduced to a matrix factorization problem. However, their attack is effective only in a particular restricted setting in which the malicious server S𝑆S (i)𝑖(i) alters the protocol execution by providing always the same parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} at each round of FL (i.e., users compute their gradient updates always on the same model fΘ~subscript𝑓~Θf_{\widetilde{\Theta}}), (i​i)𝑖𝑖(ii) leverages additional side-channel information about users’ participation in the training rounds, and (i​i​i)𝑖𝑖𝑖(iii) users are required to use the same local training dataset at each round of FL. Their approach enables the gradient inversion attack of (Zhu et al., 2019; Geiping et al., 2020; Yin et al., 2021) to scale and be effective in more realistic scenarios where there is a significant number of users participating in the protocol execution of FL. Nevertheless, its feasibility still depends on the number of active users, network parameters, and other factors such as the number of rounds that the server monitors to recover individual gradients accurately. Additionally, while the authors showed that this approach could handle noise, its applicability is inherently limited in FedSGD, where local training is performed on randomly selected batches rather than the entire, static, local dataset. Finally, this attack is not applicable in large-scale, real-world deployments of FL (Hard et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2018), where users participate in the protocol only once with a high probability.

3. Preliminaries

We use small letters (such as x𝑥x) to denote concrete values, calligraphic letters (such as 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}) to denote sets. For a string x∈\bin∗𝑥superscript\binx\in\bin^{*}, we let |x|𝑥|x| be its length; if 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} is a set, |𝒳|𝒳|\mathcal{X}| represents the cardinality of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. In the setting of deep learning, we use the notation [⋅]delimited-[]⋅[\cdot] to express a tensor (i.e., vector) of arbitrary dimension. We write [x]delimited-[]𝑥[x] for a tensor filled with the value x𝑥x. When a set is included between square brackets (e.g., [ℝ+]delimited-[]superscriptℝ[\mathbb{R}^{+}]), the tensor is filled with arbitrary elements from that set.

3.1. Neural networks

We abstract a neural layer with respect to some parameters Θ∈\RRmΘsuperscript\RR𝑚\Theta\in\RR^{m} using the following notation:

(2) ℓ​(x)=ϕ​(x⊗θ+b),ℓ𝑥italic-ϕtensor-product𝑥𝜃𝑏\ell(x)=\phi(x\otimes\theta+b),

where the symbols θ∈Θ𝜃Θ\theta\in\Theta and b∈Θ𝑏Θb\in\Theta are arbitrarily shaped real tensors333The shape of these tensors depend on the operator ⊗tensor-product\otimes. that represent the learnable parameters of the layer ℓℓ\ell. Hereafter, we refer to θ𝜃\theta and b𝑏b as the kernel and the bias, respectively. The operation ⊗tensor-product\otimes abstracts the application of the kernel on the input tensor x𝑥x. As an example, ⊗tensor-product\otimes can be a matrix multiplication operator (ℓℓ\ell is a fully connected layer), a convolution operator (ℓℓ\ell is a convolutional layer), or a more complex parametric transformation such as the multi-head attention mechanism used to build transformer networks (Vaswani et al., 2017). This definition captures other core building blocks such as normalization layers. The function ϕitalic-ϕ\phi, instead, is the activation function of ℓℓ\ell, which makes ℓℓ\ell non-linear.

A deep neural network is a function fΘ:𝒳→𝒴:subscript𝑓Θ→𝒳𝒴f_{\Theta}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} defined by the composition of many layers, i.e., fΘ​(x)=ℓn−1​(…​(ℓ1​(ℓ0​(x))))subscript𝑓Θ𝑥subscriptℓ𝑛1…subscriptℓ1subscriptℓ0𝑥f_{\Theta}(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\ell_{n-1}(\dots(\ell_{1}(\ell_{0}(x)))) where ℓi​(x)=ϕ​(x⊗θi+bi)subscriptℓ𝑖𝑥italic-ϕtensor-product𝑥subscript𝜃𝑖subscript𝑏𝑖\ell_{i}(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\phi(x\otimes\theta_{i}+b_{i}) (as defined in Equation 2), θi∈Θsubscript𝜃𝑖Θ\theta_{i}\in\Theta, bi∈Θsubscript𝑏𝑖Θb_{i}\in\Theta, and x∈𝒳𝑥𝒳x\in\mathcal{X}.

3.2. Federated learning

Federated learning (FL) allows a set of users 𝒰={u1,…,un}𝒰subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑛\mathcal{U}\leavevmode\nobreak\ =\leavevmode\nobreak\ \{u_{1},\ldots,u_{n}\}, where each uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} holds a local training dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}, to train the deep neural network fΘ:𝒳→𝒴:subscript𝑓Θ→𝒳𝒴f_{\Theta}:\mathcal{X}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y} on a global dataset that is distributed among 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}. A centralized server S𝑆S coordinates the communications between the users to train a deep neural network on 𝒟=⋃ui∈𝒰𝒟i𝒟subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝒰subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}=\bigcup_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}\mathcal{D}_{i} in such a way that each 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} does not leave the uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}’s device. The learning phase of FL is an interactive process that is divided into rounds. In the setting of FL, we denote with t𝑡t the current round of FL and we use the superscript “(t)” (sometimes in combination with the subscript “i”) to denote values used or generated (such as batches, model updates, model parameters) during the current round t𝑡t (by a particular user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}). At each round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN, the server S𝑆S (holding the parameters Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} of the deep neural network f𝑓f) sends to the subset of available users 𝒰(t)⊆𝒰superscript𝒰𝑡𝒰\mathcal{U}^{(t)}\subseteq\mathcal{U} the parameters Θ(t)∈\RRmsuperscriptΘ𝑡superscript\RR𝑚\Theta^{(t)}\in\RR^{m}.

The set 𝒰(t)superscript𝒰𝑡\mathcal{U}^{(t)} is composed of the users entitled to participate in the learning phase during the current round t𝑡t. Each uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} samples a random subset 𝒟i(t)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i} (known as batch) from its dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} and locally trains fΘ(t)subscript𝑓superscriptΘ𝑡f_{\Theta^{(t)}} on 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. The final result of the local training is a model update Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t))\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}) that is then forwarded to the server S𝑆S. The latter will be responsible of computing the new configuration Θ(t+1)superscriptΘ𝑡1\Theta^{(t+1)} of the parameters with respect to average of the model updates {Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t)}ui∈𝒰subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖𝒰\{\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\}_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}} received by the server S𝑆S. This process is iterated until the parameters ΘΘ\Theta converge.

FedSGD and FedAVG

The computation of the users’ model updates Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} and model parameters Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} vary according to the type of FL that is in place. The two main approaches are known as federated stochastic gradient descent (FedSGD) and federated averaging (FedAVG). In FedSGD, a single step of gradient descend is performed per round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN. In other words, the model update Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} (computed by a user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}) corresponds to the gradients ∇𝒟i(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscript∇superscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\nabla^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} computed with respect to the randomly chosen batch 𝒟i(t)⊆𝒟isubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}\subseteq\mathcal{D}_{i}. This gradient ∇𝒟i(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscript∇superscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\nabla^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} is set to be the model update Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} of user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. On the server side, the single step of gradient descend is executed in order to compute the new model parameter Θ(t+1)superscriptΘ𝑡1\Theta^{(t+1)} from Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} and {Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t)}ui∈𝒰subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖𝒰\{\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\}_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}. More formally, the parameters are updated as follows:

On the other hand, in FedAVG, users locally perform k∈\NN𝑘\NNk\in\NN iterations of stochastic gradient descent, producing new model parameters at each round. The complete description of the FL protocol (with FedSGD or FedAVG) is depicted in Figure 8 of the appendix.

3.3. Secure aggregation

A secure aggregation (SA) protocol is a specialized multi-party computation (MPC) protocol that allows a set of users to compute the summation (a.k.a. aggregation) of their inputs. Let 𝒰={u1,…,un}𝒰subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑛\mathcal{U}=\{u_{1},\ldots,u_{n}\} be a set of users, each holding a secret input visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} (e.g., integer, group element, vector). A protocol ΠΠ\Pi is a secure SA protocol if it securely implements the following ideal functionality:

(5) f𝗌𝖺​(v1,…,vn)=(v,…,v)for ​v=∑ui∈𝒰vi,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑓𝗌𝖺subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛𝑣…𝑣for 𝑣subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝒰subscript𝑣𝑖f^{\mathsf{sa}}(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n})=(v,\ldots,v)\quad\text{for }v=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}v_{i},

i.e., a trusted third party executes f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}} computes and returns to all users 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} the aggregation v𝑣v of the users’ inputs (v1,…,vn)subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}). Informally, a SA protocol ΠΠ\Pi is considered secure if it is at least as secure as invoking the ideal functionality f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}}. This is formalized using the standard ideal and real-world paradigm of MPC (Cramer and Damgård, 2005) (see Appendix B). The security of ΠΠ\Pi does not guarantee that nothing is leaked about other users’ inputs. Instead, it implies that nothing is leaked except what can be inferred from the final aggregation. The information that can be inferred is highly correlated to the inputs provided to f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}} (e.g., entropy).

To increase the security of FL and mitigate attacks such as gradient inversion (see Section 2), Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017) propose a communication-efficient, dropout resilient SA for FL.555In (Bonawitz et al., 2017) the aggregation v𝑣v is obtained by the server S𝑆S only. This can be represented as an ideal functionality f𝗌𝖺​(v1,…,vn,⊥)=(⊥,…,⊥,v)superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛bottombottom…bottom𝑣f^{\mathsf{sa}}(v_{1},\ldots,v_{n},\bot)=(\bot,\ldots,\bot,v) where the (n+1)𝑛1(n+1)-th input/output is associated to the server S𝑆S and ⊥bottom\bot represents the empty string. When applied to FL, the protocol guarantees a secure aggregation of users’ model updates – sensitive values that carry important information about the users’ datasets. Hence, an adversary (e.g., malicious user or server) can not observe the individual model update Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} of a target user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}. This decreases the amount of information about the local training dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i} of the target user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} that an adversary can leak (e.g., by performing gradient inversion attacks). We stress that SA protocols (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2020) have the property of being robust: The final aggregation can always be computed when at most δ𝛿\delta users drop out during the execution of the SA protocol (i.e., more than n−δ𝑛𝛿n-\delta users are online). When this condition is failed (i.e., the online users are less than n−δ𝑛𝛿n-\delta), the server cannot recover the final aggregated value. Hence, SA also guarantees that the server can only see the final aggregation when the latter contains at least n−δ𝑛𝛿n-\delta model updates (ensuring the desired level of “privacy by aggregation”).

Both Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017) and Bell et al. (Bell et al., 2020) (the most influential SA protocols in the literature) demonstrate the security of their protocols in both the semi-honest and malicious models (including collusion between server and users) (Bonawitz et al., 2017, Theorems 6.2 and 6.6) and (Bell et al., 2020, Theorems 3.6 and 4.9). However, we emphasize that the results in (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2020) cover only the security of the SA protocol. Nothing is claimed about the security of the overall FL protocol with SA enabled.

4. Threat model

In this section we formalize the threat model in which our attacks are defined (Section 5 and Section 6). We adopt the exact same threat model for which the SA protocols of Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017, Section 6.2) (CCS ’17) and Bell et al. (Bell et al., 2020, Section 4) (CCS ’20) have been demonstrated to be secure: A malicious parameter server (aggregator) that can corrupt at most a fixed number m𝑚m (out of n𝑛n) of users.666The number of corrupted users m𝑚m depends on the implementation of the SA protocol. For instance, this is ⌈n3⌉−1𝑛31\lceil\frac{n}{3}\rceil-1 for Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017). Observe that these SA protocols (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2020) are the most influential and practical-oriented solutions in the field.

More formally, in each round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN, the active users 𝒰(t)superscript𝒰𝑡\mathcal{U}^{(t)} do not send their model updates {Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t)}ui∈𝒰(t)subscriptsubscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰𝑡\{\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\}_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}} in the clear. Instead, they execute the SA protocol ΠΠ\Pi to securely compute the aggregation v=∑ui∈𝒰(t)Δ𝒟i(t)Θ(t)𝑣subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰𝑡subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖v=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}}\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} (see Section 3.3) for at least q𝑞q users. Only the final aggregation v𝑣v is revealed to the server S𝑆S. More importantly, we do not target any specific implementation of SA. In fact, our attack exploits a vulnerability caused by the incorrect usage of SA in the FL protocol. In particular, the FL protocol does not validate the inputs of SA (i.e., model updates). For this reason, to keep the attack general, we replace the execution of the underlying SA protocol with the invocation of its ideal functionality f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}} (Section 3.3).

We model an adversarial server S𝑆S whose objective is to learn information about the local dataset 𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{D}_{\mathsf{trgt}} of one (or more) target user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} that participates in the execution of the protocol, outside what can be learned from the aggregated model updates. S𝑆S can deviates from a honest execution (e.g., it sends arbitrary messages) as defined in (Bonawitz et al., 2017, Section 6.2) and (Bell et al., 2020, Section 4). Specifically, in our attacks, the malicious server S𝑆S exploits the model inconsistency attack vector; that is, S𝑆S provides arbitrary malicious parameters to arbitrary users even within the same training round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN. Although the adversarial server S𝑆S is allowed to collude with at most m𝑚m users (as considered by (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2020)), our attacks demonstrate that SA is ineffective in FL even when m=0𝑚0m\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu0, i.e., the server is malicious, but it does not collude with any user.777However, collusion with users improves the effectiveness of the attacks when additional mechanisms such as distributed differential privacy are in place. This ensures the effectiveness of the proposed attacks also outside the cross-device FL setting, where the parameter server does not perform user sub-sampling.

Lastly, we assume the standard, centralized, communication topology of FL as in real-world applications (Hard et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2018), where each user is authenticated by a PKI and shares an encrypted channel with the server S𝑆S. The SA protocols in (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2020) are designed for this communication topology. Moreover, note that a PKI is a necessary assumption. Indeed, as described in (Bonawitz et al., 2017, Section 6.2) and (Bell et al., 2020, Section 4.2), without a PKI, a server could break the privacy of users by simply launching a sybil attack. Assuming the existence of a PKI is enough to rule out such trivial sybil attacks (Bonawitz et al., 2017, Section 6.2) and (Bell et al., 2020, Section 4.2).

5. Gradient suppression attack

In this section, we present our first attack, dubbed gradient suppression, in which a malicious server exploits the model inconsistency attack vector to bypass SA and leak the model update of a chosen target user.

In a nutshell, the malicious server S𝑆S selects a target user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} among the set of active users 𝒰(t)superscript𝒰𝑡\mathcal{U}^{(t)} of the current round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN. The aim of S𝑆S is then to preserve the target’s model update during the SA process by tampering with the parameters for the other non-target users. Here, S𝑆S creates a set of malicious parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} that is sent to the non-target users 𝒰(t)∖{u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍}superscript𝒰𝑡subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{U}^{(t)}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\} whereas u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} receives the real parameters vector Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)}. The malicious Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} is crafted in such a way that the local application of gradient descent performed by a non-target users produces a tampered model update Δ𝒟i(t)Θ~subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}. The tampered model updates, when aggregated through SA, have the property of preserving the target’s model update Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}, allowing the server to recover it. Once that the target’s model update is on the server-side, S𝑆S can leak sensitive information about the batch 𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}, used during the current round t𝑡t of FL by executing an arbitrary gradient inversion attack (see Section 2.2) or related inference attacks.

Given the fact that the SA performs the sum among the users’ model updates, the simplest way to achieve the isolation of the target’s signal is to force the tampered model updates to have a negligible magnitude, or, more strictly, to be zero everywhere. In this section, we first study the extreme case Δ𝒟i(t)Θ~=[0]subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖delimited-[]0\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu[0]. That is, the aggregation of the model updates (i.e., gradients) is equal to u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}’s model update, i.e.,

f𝗌𝖺​(Δ𝒟1(t)Θ~,…,Δ𝒟i−1(t)Θ~,Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t),Δ𝒟i+1(t)Θ~,…,Δ𝒟n(t)Θ~)superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡1…subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖1subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖1…subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑛\displaystyle f^{\mathsf{sa}}(\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{1}},\ldots,\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i-1}},\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}},\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i+1}},\ldots,\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{n}})
=f𝗌𝖺​([0],…,[0],Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t),[0],…,[0])=Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)absentsuperscript𝑓𝗌𝖺delimited-[]0…delimited-[]0subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍delimited-[]0…delimited-[]0subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\displaystyle\quad=f^{\mathsf{sa}}([0],\ldots,[0],\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}},[0],\ldots,[0])=\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}

allowing S𝑆S to exactly recover Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}. Figure 1 depicts the gradient suppression attack against FedSGD. We stress that the attack applies to FedAVG as we will discuss in Section 5.2.

Next, we show how to compute the malicious parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} required to perform the gradient suppression attack. We focus on the most widely adopted class of deep learning models—the one based on the ReLU activation function. However, in Appendix C, we show that our approach extends to arbitrarily composed architectures.

5.1. Gradient suppression for ReLU layers: The dead-layer trick

The Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU) activation function:

(6) R​e​L​U​(x)={xif ​x>00if ​x≤0𝑅𝑒𝐿𝑈𝑥cases𝑥if 𝑥00if 𝑥0ReLU(x)=\begin{cases}x&\text{if }x>0\\ 0&\text{if }x\leq 0\end{cases}

is one of the core technical improvements that led to deep learning (Nair and Hinton, 2010). Nowadays, this function is ubiquitous in computer vision architectures, representing the core building block of highly successful and standardized models such as ResNet (He et al., 2016), DenseNet (Huang et al., 2017) and many others. Outside the computer vision domain, the ReLU activation function is currently finding its place in Natural Language Processing (NLP) applications thanks to the success of transformer networks (Vaswani et al., 2017; Radford et al., 2019; Brown et al., 2020).

The dying-ReLU problem (Lu, 2020) is a phenomenon that naturally occurs during the training of deep neural networks that rely on the ReLU activation function. When a layer ℓℓ\ell “dies”, it enters a state where it can only produce a constant output. More importantly, the dead layer ℓℓ\ell cannot produce any gradient during the gradient descent iterations, i.e., the derivatives of its trainable parameters are zero regardless of the given input and loss function.

Despite the dying-ReLU phenomenon can naturally occur, we show that it can also be intentionally induced by a malicious server to prevent a network from producing a gradient for one or more sets of parameters. Next, we describe how this can be achieved and exploited to perform our gradient suppression attack.

5.1.1. Triggering the Dying-ReLU phenomenon with malicious parameters

The Dying-ReLU phenomenon is due to the piece-wise non-differentiability of the ReLU activation function. Consider a neural layer ℓℓ\ell with a R​e​L​U𝑅𝑒𝐿𝑈ReLU activation function, i.e., ℓ​(x)=R​e​L​U​(x⊗θ+b)ℓ𝑥𝑅𝑒𝐿𝑈tensor-product𝑥𝜃𝑏\ell(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5muReLU(x\otimes\theta+b). From Equation 6, we can see that the ReLU function behaves as a constant function R​e​L​U​(x)=0𝑅𝑒𝐿𝑈𝑥0ReLU(x)=0, whenever the input x𝑥x is equal or less than zero. Since the derivative of a constant function is always 00, we can easily conclude that, for any loss function ℒℒ\mathcal{L}, then we have ∂ℒ∂θ=[0]ℒ𝜃delimited-[]0\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial\theta}=[0] and ∂ℒ∂b=[0]ℒ𝑏delimited-[]0\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial b}=[0] when x⊗θ+b≤0tensor-product𝑥𝜃𝑏0x\otimes\theta+b\leq 0. In other words, the layer ℓℓ\ell receives zero gradient for its trainable parameters θ,b∈Θ𝜃𝑏Θ\theta,b\in\Theta every time its pre-activation (i.e., x⊗θ+btensor-product𝑥𝜃𝑏x\otimes\theta+b) is less or equal to zero.

A malicious server S𝑆S can exploit the above behavior of the ReLU function to kill a layer ℓℓ\ell of a neural network f𝑓f, i.e., by forcing the pre-activation x⊗θ+btensor-product𝑥𝜃𝑏x\otimes\theta+b of ℓℓ\ell to be less or equal to zero. This can be accomplished (without control over the input x𝑥x of an user) by computing some malicious trainable parameters θ~,b~∈Θ~~𝜃~𝑏~Θ\widetilde{\theta},\widetilde{b}\in\widetilde{\Theta} of the layer ℓℓ\ell.

In more detail, the operator ⊗tensor-product\otimes (see Section 3.1) is generally based on a multiplication-like operation between the input x𝑥x and the kernel θ𝜃\theta. Therefore, we can easily force the pre-activation to be [0]delimited-[]0[0] for any input x𝑥x by just choosing θ~=[0]~𝜃delimited-[]0\widetilde{\theta}=[0] and b~=[ℝ≤0]~𝑏delimited-[]subscriptℝabsent0\widetilde{b}=[\mathbb{R}_{\leq 0}]. Alternatively, having some knowledge on the input x𝑥x, we can rely on different setups for θ~~𝜃\widetilde{\theta} and b~~𝑏\widetilde{b}. For instance, if x𝑥x is strictly positive (e.g., because x𝑥x is the output produced by a previous ReLU-layer or because of the adopted input normalization process), it is enough to produce a malicious θ~~𝜃\widetilde{\theta} with negative numbers. Instead, if a bound on x𝑥x is known (e.g., x∈[−1,1]𝑥11x\in[-1,1]), we can just set the malicious bias vector b~~𝑏\widetilde{b} to a large enough negative number (e.g., fix θ~~𝜃\widetilde{\theta} and set b~=−m​a​x​(θ~​⨂x)~𝑏𝑚𝑎𝑥~𝜃tensor-product𝑥\widetilde{b}=-max(\widetilde{\theta}\bigotimes x)).

Now, an attacker can exploit the dead-layer trick to force a ReLU-based network to produce zero gradient for every layer. In this direction, it is important to note that, for plain, ReLU-based feedforward architectures, the server S𝑆S can just kill the kernels in the very first layer to suppress the gradient flow for the rest of the network.888However, if present, all the bias terms of the network should be set to values ≤0absent0\leq 0. Hence, killing all the kernels {θi}subscript𝜃𝑖\{\theta_{i}\} in the original parameters ΘΘ\Theta is very often not necessary. Similarly, in modern architectures, neural layers tend to be arranged in the form:

neural layer→normalization layer→activation.→neural layernormalization layer→activation\text{neural layer}\rightarrow\text{normalization layer}\rightarrow\text{activation}.

Therefore, to suppress the gradient for the network, it is enough to zero only the parameters of the normalization layers as these are often defined as γ​x^+β𝛾^𝑥𝛽\gamma\hat{x}+\beta, where x^^𝑥\hat{x} is the normalized input. For instance, in the case of batch normalization, the attacker can kill the neural layer by setting the vectors γ𝛾{\gamma} and β𝛽{\beta} of the batch normalization to [0]delimited-[]0[0]. Nevertheless, the strategy would work for every architectural configuration.

Moreover, even if ReLU is the most common activation function in deep learning, a server S𝑆S can always maliciously choose a neural network architecture f𝑓f that presents a ReLU activation function in the “right spots” of the model without requiring unrealistic architecture modifications. The only gradient signal that cannot be recovered by the server using the dead-ReLU trick is the one of the bias term of the last layer (details are given in Appendix C). This follows from the fact that the terminal layer of a network only rarely exhibits a ReLU activation function. A trivial solution for the malicious server is to avoid the bias term of the last layer when defining the architecture of the model. Alternatively, the malicious server can ignore the gradient of the bias term during the gradient inversion. Indeed, this represents only a tiny portion of the total number of trainable parameters of the network. For instance, in the case of a ResNet50 trained on ImageNet (He et al., 2016), the bias vector in the final layer counts for only 4⋅10−5%⋅4percentsuperscript1054\cdot 10^{-5}\% of the total number of parameters. In Section 5.2.2, we show that gradient inversion is unaffected from this missing gradient.

5.2. Attack execution

Turning back to the attack described at the beginning of this section, we have now an effective and efficient approach to isolate the model update Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of the target user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. The malicious server S𝑆S can just exploit the techniques discussed in Section 5.1 and Appendix C to generate the malicious parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} and suppress the model updates of non-target users, completely nullifying their contributions in the aggregated signal produced by SA. As previously described (Figure 1), the attack is composed of two phases.

5.2.1. Distribution of the (malicious) parameters

In the first phase of the attack, S𝑆S creates the malicious parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} for the non-target users. Right after the choice of Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta}, S𝑆S must choose the target user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} for the current round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN of FL. S𝑆S can either select the target at random (a trawling attack) from 𝒰(t)superscript𝒰𝑡\mathcal{U}^{(t)} or target a specific (e.g., exploiting the IP address used to query the model by the user, if available). Then, S𝑆S can enforce the model inconsistency by distributing the parameters (Figure 1). In more detail, upon receiving a request for the parameters from a user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, the parameter server answers by sending Θi(t)subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑖\Theta^{(t)}_{i} defined as follows:

(7) Θi(t)={Θ(t)if ​i=𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍Θ~otherwise,subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑖casessuperscriptΘ𝑡if 𝑖𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍~Θotherwise\Theta^{(t)}_{i}=\begin{cases}\Theta^{(t)}&\text{if }i=\mathsf{trgt}\\ \widetilde{\Theta}&\text{otherwise}\end{cases},

where Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} are the honest parameters of the current round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN. Optionally, S𝑆S can send a maliciously crafted model to the target user to increase the information recovered from the inversion attack (Geiping et al., 2020; Fowl et al., 2021).

5.2.2. Aggregation, collection, and inversion

After the distribution of the parameters, the malicious server S𝑆S waits until it receives the output v𝑣v of f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}}, i.e., f𝗌𝖺​(Δ𝒟1(t)Θ~,…,Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t),…,Δ𝒟n(t)Θ~)=vsuperscript𝑓𝗌𝖺subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡1…subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍…subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑛𝑣f^{\mathsf{sa}}(\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{1}},\ldots,\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}},\ldots,\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{n}})=v where

(8) v=Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)+∑ui∈𝒰(t)∖{u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍}Δ𝒟i(t)Θ~.𝑣subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰𝑡subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\displaystyle v=\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}+\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\}}\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}.

Then, it proceeds differently according to which algorithm (between FedSGD or FedAVG) is active.

In FedSGD, the output v𝑣v of f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}} is the u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}’s gradient, i.e., v=Δ𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)=∇𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)𝑣subscriptsuperscriptΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscriptsuperscript∇superscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍v\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}\allowbreak\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\nabla^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}. This is because, as discussed earlier, the malicious parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} produces Δ𝒟i(t)Θ~=[0]subscriptsuperscriptΔ~Θsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖delimited-[]0\Delta^{\widetilde{\Theta}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu[0] for each non-target user ui∈𝒰(t)∖{u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍}subscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰𝑡subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\} (Section 5.1 and Appendix C). After recovering the plaintext gradient, the server can reconstruct the target input by performing standard inversion attacks (Section 2.2) as done in the protocol without SA. Figure 2 reports examples of gradient inversion on the federated system with gradient recovered via the gradient suppression attack. In the examples, we keep the bias term of the last layer in the architecture and ignore it during the optimization (Geiping et al., 2020). Note that the attack is independent of the number of users participating in the aggregation, and this can be arbitrarily large. Similarly, the server can perform previously proposed inference attacks (Nasr et al., 2019; Melis et al., 2019) on the individual user.

On the other hand, in FedAVG, a model update is composed of the parameters of the local model rather than a gradient (see Section 3.2). More formally,

(9) Δ𝒟i(t)Θi(t)subscriptsuperscriptΔsubscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\Delta^{\Theta^{(t)}_{i}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}} =Θi(t,k)absentsubscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑘𝑖\displaystyle=\Theta^{(t,k)}_{i} for ​ui∈𝒰(t),for subscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰𝑡\displaystyle\text{ for }u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)},
