Once the malicious server S𝑆S recovered the updated local model Θ𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t,k)subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑘𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\Theta^{(t,k)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} of the target u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}, it can determine the (pseudo) gradient signal by removing the honest parameters Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} from Θ𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t,k)subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑘𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\Theta^{(t,k)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} and proceed with the gradient inversion/inference attack.

5.3. Impact

Current FL+SA implementations do not prevent the gradient suppression attack, making users actively susceptible to this simple yet powerful exploit. To a certain extent, this attack can be interpreted as an invalid input validation vulnerability present in the users’ FL client software. Here, the latter permits users to perform computation on “semantically malformed inputs” sent by a non-trusted party, i.e., the server. This allows the server to control SA’s inputs of users and eventually affect the aggregation. Furthermore, in contrast to most of the previous attacks introduced in FL, the disclosed vulnerability has the practical advantage of being completely independent of the number of users participating in the current round. Therefore, this procedure scales to millions of active users, making it applicable to real-world scenarios such as cross-device FL, which is currently being deployed in-the-wild (Hard et al., 2019; Yang et al., 2018). In the same direction, its effectiveness is independent of the size of the model or other nuisance factors such as the stillness of users’ training datasets during the attack (Lam et al., 2021). Additionally, unlike (Fowl et al., 2021), this attack neither hinges on auxiliary information on the users’ private sets nor requires unrealistic modifications of the model architecture; indeed, it can be applied to arbitrary architectures and loss functions. It is important to note that the gradient suppression attack can be iterated several times and arbitrarily alternated with honest training iterations. If the server wants to recover information on all the users, it has to iterate the attack several times by targeting a user at a time. Assuming no dropouts among users participating at the FL protocol, recovering the gradient of all users requires n𝑛n iterations where n𝑛n is the number of active users.

We stress that the gradient suppression attack shows the incorrect application of SA in FL, yielding a “false sense of security”. As discussed in Section 1.1, the core motivation is that SA guarantees that nothing is leaked about the model updates of the users except what can be inferred from their aggregation. This claim assumes that the inputs (i.e., model updates) of SA are fixed and are not under the control of an adversary. However, this does not hold in FL since, in this case, the value of inputs that needs to be aggregated depends on the parameters ΘΘ\Theta distributed by the server. Hence, a malicious server that executes the gradient suppression attack can indirectly tamper with the SA’s inputs to maximize the information leaked (e.g., leak the model update of a target user).

Although the gradient suppression attack is highly effective, it can be easily detected by non-target users (we delve into this topic in Section 7). Nevertheless, in the next Section 6 we introduce an extension of the gradient suppression attack that adds stealthiness and it is harder to detect. More generally, one can always trade effectiveness for stealthiness also in the gradient suppression framework. For instance, if recovering noisy model updates is acceptable, the server can send highly optimized models (e.g., obtained after some rounds of honest execution) to non-targets and an unoptimized model to the target. Intuitively, the gradient from the unoptimized model should dominate the aggregation given the low magnitude and sparsity of the one produced by the optimized models (see Figure 4).

6. Canary-gradient attack for property inference

Section 5 demonstrates that a malicious server S𝑆S can force non-target users to produce a zero gradient during a round of FL. This allows S𝑆S to bypass SA and, at the same time, maximize the leakage regarding the dataset of a target user. While the gradient suppression attack can be seen as the most extreme exploitation of the model inconsistency attack vector, more stealthy attacks can be created harnessing the same underlying intuition.

This section shows a general procedure that allows a malicious server to perform highly accurate property inference attacks on individual users, even if SA is enabled. The idea behind this approach is that the server can maliciously modify the parameters of the model in order to inject specific detectors in one or more subsets of the network. These detectors are specifically crafted to react to attacker-chosen trigger conditions that can be present in the users’ training instances. Whether the detector is triggered during the local training procedure, the network produces a clear footprint in the model update. Then, upon receiving the latter from a user, the server can determine if the trigger condition has been met by looking for the footprint in the model update. This allows the server to infer information on the content of the user’s training set; that is, the presence or absence of data with the specific property. For instance, using this approach, the server can perform an extremely accurate membership inference on a chosen target user. Hereafter, we refer to this general procedure as the canary-gradient attack.

As for the gradient suppression, the canary-gradient attack does not target any specific SA protocol but instead leverages a vulnerability of FL caused by its incorrect usage of SA. For this reason, we abstract the SA protocol with its ideal functionality f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}}.

6.1. The Conditional Dead-Layer trick

The main building block to construct the attack is a conditioned version of the dead-layer trick of Section 5.1. Informally, we want to “kill” a layer only if the instance x∈𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍x\in\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} of the target u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} satisfies a particular condition. In other words, we would like a programmed death through the backdooring of the layer. For the sake of presentation, we introduce the conditional dead-layer trick assuming that SA is disabled. Then, in Section 6.2 we extend the discussion to the case of SA enabled.

Formally, given a layer ℓℓ\ell, we want to find some malicious parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} to enforce the following behavior

(11) ∂ℒ​(𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t),Θ~)∂ξ≠0⟺∃x∈𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t):P​(x)=𝖳𝗋𝗎𝖾,⟺ℒsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍~Θ𝜉0𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍:𝑃𝑥𝖳𝗋𝗎𝖾\frac{\partial\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}},\widetilde{\Theta})}{\partial\xi}\neq 0\Longleftrightarrow\exists x\in\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}:P(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\mathsf{True},

where 𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} is the batch (of the current round t𝑡t) used by the target user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}, ξ∈Θ~𝜉~Θ\xi\in\widetilde{\Theta} is a subset parameters of the network, and P𝑃P is a predicate that defines the property the malicious server S𝑆S wants to detect in the batch 𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} of u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. In particular, ξ𝜉\xi can be composed of the parameters of any logic partition in the neural network, such as a specific filter in a convolution layer or an element in the scale and shift vectors in a normalization layer.

As discussed in Section 5, suppressing the gradient for a set of parameters in a ReLU-based layer is about controlling the value of its pre-activation. Therefore, given a neural layer ℓℓ\ell with ReLU activation, we can substitute Equation 11 with:

(12) ℓξ=(xξ⊗θξ+bξ)>0⟺∃x∈𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t):P​(x)=𝖳𝗋𝗎𝖾,⟺subscriptℓ𝜉tensor-productsubscript𝑥𝜉subscript𝜃𝜉subscript𝑏𝜉0𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍:𝑃𝑥𝖳𝗋𝗎𝖾\ell_{\xi}\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu(x_{\xi}\otimes\theta_{\xi}+b_{\xi})>0\Longleftrightarrow\exists x\in\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}:P(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\mathsf{True},

where ξ={θξ,bξ}𝜉subscript𝜃𝜉subscript𝑏𝜉\xi=\{\theta_{\xi},b_{\xi}\}, and xξsubscript𝑥𝜉x_{\xi} is the subset of the input of ℓℓ\ell that interacts with the parameters ξ𝜉\xi and ℓξsubscriptℓ𝜉\ell_{\xi} refers to the subset of the output of the layer ℓℓ\ell computed using the parameters ξ𝜉\xi.

The simplest and most natural way to find ξ𝜉\xi that correctly induce Equation 12 is to explicitly train the layers preceding ℓℓ\ell and the parameters ξ𝜉\xi to force ℓξsubscriptℓ𝜉\ell_{\xi} to produce a positive value only when the input of the network satisfies P𝑃P. In other words, we train part of the network in a classification task, using the output ℓξsubscriptℓ𝜉\ell_{\xi} such as the output layer, where the classification threshold is centered in zero. Observe that, if the behavior of Equation 12 is correctly embedded in the network fΘ~subscript𝑓~Θf_{\widetilde{\Theta}}, a malicious server S𝑆S will able to determine the event ∃x∈𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t):P​(x)=𝗍𝗋𝗎𝖾:𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍𝑃𝑥𝗍𝗋𝗎𝖾\exists x\in\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}:P(x)\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu\mathsf{true} by only collecting gradient ∇𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)ξsubscriptsuperscript∇𝜉subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} and check that the derivatives of ξ𝜉\xi are different from zero. In Section 6.3 we show how this can be done in practice.

6.2. Targeted property inference attacks via model inconsistency

To perform the membership inference attack discussed in the previous section, the malicious server S𝑆S needs to have access to the gradient ∇𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)ξsubscriptsuperscript∇𝜉subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} of u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. This is possible when SA is disabled. On the other hand, when SA is enabled, the S𝑆S can inject the canary-gradient functionality in the network and then perform the inference attack on the whole pool of active users. In this scenario, S𝑆S would be able to infer that one of the users triggered the canary-gradient by observing that fξ𝗌𝖺​(∇𝒟1(t)ξ,…,∇𝒟n(t)ξ)=∑ui∈𝒰(t)∇𝒟i(t)ξ≠[0]subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝗌𝖺𝜉subscriptsuperscript∇𝜉subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡1…subscriptsuperscript∇𝜉subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑛subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰𝑡subscriptsuperscript∇𝜉subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖delimited-[]0f^{\mathsf{sa}}_{\xi}(\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{1}},\ldots,\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{n}})=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}}\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\neq[0] where fξ𝗌𝖺subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝗌𝖺𝜉f^{\mathsf{sa}}_{\xi} denotes the inner idealized functionality of f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}} that performs the aggregation of the gradients of ξ𝜉\xi. However, in this case, the privacy of users would be partially preserved as S𝑆S would not be able to attribute the result of the inference attack to a specific user (“privacy by shuffling”).

Still, we show that model inconsistency can be exploited even in this case, allowing the malicious server S𝑆S to bypass SA and target the specific target u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. Analogously to the gradient suppression attack (Section 5), S𝑆S needs to tamper with the honest parameters Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} in order to produce two different malicious Θ~1subscript~Θ1\widetilde{\Theta}_{1} and Θ~2subscript~Θ2\widetilde{\Theta}_{2}. The target user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} will receive Θ~1subscript~Θ1\widetilde{\Theta}_{1} that is the original model Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} injected with a canary-gradient for the parameters ξ𝜉\xi as discussed in Section 6.1. On the other hand, the non-target users 𝒰(t)∖{u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍}superscript𝒰𝑡subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{U}^{(t)}\setminus\{u_{\mathsf{trgt}}\} will receive Θ~2subscript~Θ2\widetilde{\Theta}_{2} that is a slight perturbation of the original model Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} that has the additional property of unconditionally produce zero-gradient only for the parameters ξ𝜉\xi, i.e., ∇𝒟i(t)ξ=[0]subscriptsuperscript∇𝜉subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝑖delimited-[]0\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{i}}\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu[0]. This can be achieved by exploiting the dead-layer trick in a localized way. Instead of killing the gradient for the whole layer, it intentionally inhibits only the gradient produced by the parameters ξ𝜉\xi; for instance, for just one filter in a convolution layer.

Now, when the target and non-target gradients are aggregated, the target’s gradient ∇𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)ξsubscriptsuperscript∇𝜉subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\nabla^{\xi}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} for ξ𝜉\xi will be preserved, allowing the server to state the activation or non-activation of the canary-gradient, and so, with high probability, the presence of the property P𝑃P in the batch 𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} of u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}}. This intuition is captured by Figure 3.

Finally, given that the number of parameters in ξ𝜉\xi can be arbitrarily small, the attack will leave only a minimal footprint, making the detection non-trivial (in our experiments, we show that two parameters are enough). This is also supported by the fact that the gradient becomes more sparse as the training proceeds (see Figure 4), making it difficult to distinguish between natural “holes” and artificial ones in the gradient vector.

While we gave an abstract view on the attack strategy, next, we show how the attack can be carried out on a realistic architecture such as ResNet in a membership inference attack scenario.

6.3. Injecting canary-gradient for membership inference

We show a practical example of how to model a membership attack on the training dataset of a specific user. Specifically, we target training instance xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}, and we want to infer if xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} is contained in the batch 𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}} used by the target user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} to compute the gradient update in the current round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN of FL. Following previous notation, we want to infer the following property:

Pxt​(x)=𝖳𝗋𝗎𝖾⟺x=xt.⟺subscript𝑃subscript𝑥𝑡𝑥𝖳𝗋𝗎𝖾𝑥subscript𝑥𝑡P_{x_{t}}(x)=\mathsf{True}\Longleftrightarrow x=x_{t}.

We start by considering the case of FedSGD and carry out the attack on a ResNet20 network. However, for this network, we do not consider the batch normalization layers as those would make the attack trivial. Indeed, if batch normalization is used, we could detect the activation of ℓξsubscriptℓ𝜉\ell_{\xi} by checking the average computed and sent to the server to update the running mean. For this reason, we keep the attack general by substituting every batch normalization with layer normalization (Ba et al., 2016) that does not present this issue and has an overlapping role. We then extend the attack to FedAVG in Appendix D.

In our experiment, we inject the canary gradient in the last residual block of the network. This is because the terminal layers are usually the ones that receive the sparsest gradient during the training. Since the normalization layer precedes the ReLU activation function, we chose a subset of the parameters of the latter as our ξ𝜉\xi. In particular, we can pick any pair (γi,βi)subscript𝛾𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖(\gamma_{i},\beta_{i}) in the scale and shift vectors γ𝛾\gamma and β𝛽\beta. Thus, in this case, ξ𝜉\xi is composed of only two parameters, that is about 7⋅10−4%⋅7percentsuperscript1047\cdot 10^{-4}\% of the total number of parameters in the network. Hereafter, we always choose i=0𝑖0i=0; however, choosing a different channel would not affect the attack.

To inject the canary gradient, we use a learning-based approach. In this direction, we assume that the adversary (i.e., malicious server) knows a shadow dataset 𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s} defined in the same domain of the target point xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}. For instance, if xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} is a face image, 𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s} contains face images as well. We stress that, as we will show later, the distribution of 𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s} and one of the users’ datasets can be different. Intuitively, the role of 𝒟ssubscript𝒟𝑠\mathcal{D}_{s} is providing negative samples while training ℓξsubscriptℓ𝜉\ell_{\xi} to fire on xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}. It is important to note that the canary-gradient attack is agnostic, and the simple training procedure discussed can be substituted with other techniques. For instance, approaches such as (Fowl et al., 2021) and learning-based approaches that do not require negative samples (i.e., one-class classification) may be used to reach the same result. In this direction, our main contribution is introducing the idea that the server can manipulate the derivative of the current model to encode arbitrary messages (and that these messages can be retrieved under SA).

We can now inject the canary gradient by reducing the malicious injection to a classification problem. We train the split of the network up to ξ𝜉\xi in producing positive ℓξsubscriptℓ𝜉\ell_{\xi} when the network’s input contains xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}. In our case, with ξ={γi,βi}𝜉subscript𝛾𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖\xi=\{\gamma_{i},\beta_{i}\}, we have ℓξ=γi​xi¯+βisubscriptℓ𝜉subscript𝛾𝑖¯subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖\ell_{\xi}=\gamma_{i}\bar{x_{i}}+\beta_{i}, where x¯¯𝑥\bar{x} is the normalized input of the layer. Our loss function ℒℒ\mathcal{L} for a batch of size n𝑛n is simply defined as the binary cross entropy:

(13) −1n​∑i=1n{α1⋅log⁡(sigmoid​(ℓξ))if ​x=xtα0⋅log⁡(1−sigmoid​(ℓξ))otherwise,1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛cases⋅subscript𝛼1sigmoidsubscriptℓ𝜉if 𝑥subscript𝑥𝑡⋅subscript𝛼01sigmoidsubscriptℓ𝜉otherwise-\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\begin{cases}\alpha_{1}\cdot\log(\texttt{sigmoid}(\ell_{\xi}))&\text{if }x=x_{t}\\ \alpha_{0}\cdot\log(1-\texttt{sigmoid}(\ell_{\xi}))&\text{otherwise}\end{cases},

where instances different from xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} are sampled from Dssubscript𝐷𝑠D_{s}, and α1subscript𝛼1\alpha_{1} and α0subscript𝛼0\alpha_{0} weight the loss for the two events. In other words, we want to “overfit” the network to produce positive ℓξsubscriptℓ𝜉\ell_{\xi} only for the point xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t}, while squashing under 00 the feature-space around it. This intuition is depicted in Figure 5. We stop the training when we reach a training loss lower than a given threshold.

Finally, the gradient for ξ𝜉\xi in the non-target users is unconditionally suppressed by just setting both γi=βi=0subscript𝛾𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖0\gamma_{i}=\beta_{i}=0, but other configurations are possible.

6.3.1. Results

We evaluated the effectiveness of our attack. We test three different image datasets, namely, CIFAR10, CIFAR100 (Krizhevsky, 2009), and TinyImagenet (Chrabaszcz et al., 2017). We use all the possible permutations of those datasets to represent the private and shadow distribution for the canary-gradient attack, obtaining 666 different configurations.

To run the experiments, we pick xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} (i.e., the target of the membership inference) at random from the validation set of the private dataset. Then, we trained the model by injecting the canary-gradient in the channel 00 of the last normalization layer in the last residual block. After the injection, we evaluated the canary’s effectiveness by testing that the canary-gradient is non-zero when xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} is in the training batch and zero otherwise. To this end, we iterate over all the training data of the private dataset by selecting a batch 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} of size n𝑛n at a time. Given 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, we compute the gradient according to the original loss function and test that ξ𝜉\xi has gradient zero (precision). Then, we insert xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} in 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}, and we test if the gradient of ξ𝜉\xi is different from zero (recall). We perform the test on the three private datasets with different batch sizes and repeat the test for 505050 different xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} for every case.We report our results in Figure 6, where we use the notation “private-dataset←←\leftarrowshadow-dataset”.

The canary gradient has perfect recall (i.e., if xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} is in the batch, the canary is always triggered), but it can be subject to false-positive errors with low probability. The global accuracy of the method is about 99%percent9999\% for a batch size up to 128128128. The precision of the attacks slowly decreases when the batch size becomes larger. This follows from the fact that larger batches have more probability of including at least one “false trigger example” that causes a false positive. Intuitively, false positives are instances that induce a feature representation that is similar to the target one; a few examples are given in Figure 7. Therefore, while false triggers reduce the accuracy of the attack, these can still inform the attacker that instances similar to xtsubscript𝑥𝑡x_{t} are present in the victim’s local training set. The attacker can intentionally tune the definition of similarity by introducing the desired inductive bias in the canary injection process.999For instance, the server can train the canary to intentionally react only to “red cars”, by training it accordingly. Regardless of the presence of false triggers, the attack is appreciably precise; the accuracy remains higher than 96%percent9696\% even in the worst configuration. The canary-gradient attack also applies to FedAVG by just requiring minimal effort to the malicious parameter server. In Appendix D, we empirically demonstrate the effectiveness of this approach.

6.4. Impact

Although we presented the canary-gradient attack to execute a membership inference, the same approach can be applied to any type of property inference. Ideally, it is sufficient to define a different trigger condition and train the network accordingly. Moreover, the server can inject multiple canary-gradient with different triggers in the same network and infer non-binary properties. In the same direction, the server can simultaneously perform inference on multiple users without losing accuracy by carefully managing the allocation of conditional and unconditional dead-layers.

More importantly, the canary-gradient attack maintains the same practical properties as the gradient-suppression attack; mainly, it requires only a training round to perform, its effectiveness is independent of the number of users participating in the round, and it is loss agnostic (i.e., it works for any learning task). However, unlike the gradient suppression approach, this leaves only a minimal footprint in the model updates. Note that the canary gradient can be injected while training the model on the original task, and so minimizing the utility loss of the target model. On the other hand, suppressing a limited number of parameters in the non-target models (e.g., two in our example) has only a negligible impact on the utility.101010This is equivalent to perform dropout (Srivastava et al., 2014) on a single channel on a single layer in the network.

This attack demonstrates that a malicious server can perform highly accurate property inference attacks on individual users even if SA is adopted from the latter. Again, the introduced training-based approach is just an example, and more sophisticated techniques may be devised to reach the same (or better) results by relying on the same general construction.

For completeness, we emphasize that, even in the case of canary-gradient attacks, the discussion about the insecurity of the combination of SA and FL applies (discussed in Sections 1.1 and 5.3). As for the case of gradient suppression, the canary-gradient works if the SA protocol is perfectly secure (i.e., it behaves as the ideal functionality f𝗌𝖺superscript𝑓𝗌𝖺f^{\mathsf{sa}}).

7. Mitigations

Next, we will discuss and introduce some mitigation approaches.

The first part focuses on heuristic approaches that strive to prevent model inconsistency and attack vectors similar to those seen in this work. While they do not stop all possible attacks, their practical relevance is still significant.

Then, we analyze how combining DP with SA can lead to a more general mitigation strategy.

7.1. Heuristic mitigations against model inconsistency

SA dropout

Although the gradient suppression attack (Section 5) is effective, it can be detected easily by non-target users. Indeed, non-target users can quickly discover an ongoing attack as their models would have zero gradients throughout.111111A phenomenon that is very unlikely to be observed in reality, excluding numerical errors or pathologic overfitting. However, the target (who is the victim of the attack) cannot detect or prevent the attack without communicating with non-target users.121212Note that the standard implementation of FL does not allow users to communicate. Therefore, a solution could be instructing users not to execute the SA protocol when they detect a null gradient after a local training iteration. In this case, only the attack victims would participate in the SA protocol, which is enough to prevent the server from recovering the target’s model update. Indeed, the server would not receive enough information to unmask the target model’s update and complete the execution of SA. This is because the dropout threshold δ𝛿\delta of the underlying SA protocol (i.e., the number of user dropout that the SA protocol can handle) must be set to δ<n−1𝛿𝑛1\delta<n-1 where n𝑛n is the number of users participating in the aggregation (otherwise, if δ=n−1𝛿𝑛1\delta=n-1, a malicious user can unmask the gradients of other users). See (Bonawitz et al., 2017) for more details. Nevertheless, this detection strategy does not work in the case of the canary-gradient attack (Section 6). The “negligible” footprint of the model update does not allow for a reliable detection since sparse model updates are common in an honest execution of FL (see Figure 4).

Parameter validation using signatures

Another approach consists of checking that all users have received the same parameters Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} in the current round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN of FL. For example, each ui∈𝒰(t)subscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰𝑡u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)} sends the parameters Θi(t)subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑖\Theta^{(t)}_{i} (or its hash) sent by S𝑆S to all other users. Then, each ui∈𝒰(t)subscript𝑢𝑖superscript𝒰𝑡u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)} checks that

(14) Θi(t)=Θj(t)​ for every ​ui,uj∈𝒰(t).formulae-sequencesubscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑗 for every subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑗superscript𝒰𝑡\Theta^{(t)}_{i}=\Theta^{(t)}_{j}\text{ for every }u_{i},u_{j}\in\mathcal{U}^{(t)}.

If the check fails, the user aborts. It is easy to see that this strategy does not allow S𝑆S to execute model inconsistency attacks (note that it can still send a malicious parameters Θ~~Θ\widetilde{\Theta} to all). Unfortunately, in the standard communication topology of FL (see Section 4), users do not have a direct communication channel. Each message needs to go through the server that, in turn, will forward the message to the intended receiver. Hence, a malicious server can perform a man-in-the-middle attack and substitute each Θi(t)subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑖\Theta^{(t)}_{i} sent by uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} with an arbitrary honest-looking parameters ΘΘ\Theta. If we want to preserve the communication topology of FL, digital signatures must be involved. For example, assuming that each uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} holds a key pair (s​ki,p​ki)𝑠subscript𝑘𝑖𝑝subscript𝑘𝑖(sk_{i},pk_{i}) then uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} needs to (i)𝑖(i) sign its message before sending it to the server S𝑆S and, (i​i)𝑖𝑖(ii) verify the signature (using the public key p​kj𝑝subscript𝑘𝑗pk_{j} of the signee) of each message received. If the security of the signature holds, then the server can not change the messages of users. As a consequence, users are guaranteed that the message is honest, and they can perform the check defined in Equation 14. We stress that this approach works under the assumption that users 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} can trust and know (in advance) the public keys of all other users (e.g., there is a trusted certification authority). Note that this assumption is at the root of the SA protocols of Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017) and Bell et al. (Bell et al., 2020).

This approach would add one round of communication without modifying the implementation of the underlying SA protocol. However, this round could be merged with the ones of SA, e.g., the third round of the SA protocol of Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017, Figure 2). Regarding the communication complexity, exchanging the signatures of the received parameters increases communication by n⋅ℓ⋅𝑛ℓn\cdot\ell where n𝑛n is the number of active users and ℓℓ\ell is the size of one signature (e.g., 256256256 bits).

Conditional secure aggregation

Another mitigation consists of building a modified SA version for FL that performs the aggregation only if a particular condition C𝐶C is satisfied. Otherwise, it outputs a random value (or fixed value ⊥bottom\bot denoting that the aggregation did not occur). Intuitively, by setting the condition C𝐶C to Equation 14, the FL protocol executes the aggregation (and continue its execution) only if all the users have received the same parameters Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} in the current round t∈\NN𝑡\NNt\in\NN. This would hinder a malicious server S𝑆S from exploiting the model inconsistency attack vector. Naturally, such a protocol can be built leveraging general MPC techniques. However, this would yield an inefficient aggregation that will not be deployed in practice. A candidate practical implementation of this SA for the specialized condition of Equation 14 can be easily obtained by modifying the SA protocol of Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017). Still, we stress that this approach can also be applied to the SA protocol of Bell et al. (Bell et al., 2020). In a nutshell, in (Bonawitz et al., 2017) (and (Bell et al., 2020)) there is an ordering over the users 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} and each pair (ui,uj)subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑗(u_{i},u_{j}) such that ui≠ujsubscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑗u_{i}\neq u_{j} share a random secret si,jsubscript𝑠𝑖𝑗s_{i,j}. During the aggregation, each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} masks its input visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} in the following way:

yisubscript𝑦𝑖\displaystyle y_{i} =vi+∑uj∈𝒰:ui<ujG​(si,j)−∑uj∈𝒰:ui>ujG​(sj,i)absentsubscript𝑣𝑖subscript:subscript𝑢𝑗𝒰subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑗𝐺subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗subscript:subscript𝑢𝑗𝒰subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑢𝑗𝐺subscript𝑠𝑗𝑖\displaystyle=v_{i}+\sum_{u_{j}\in\mathcal{U}:u_{i}<u_{j}}G(s_{i,j})-\sum_{u_{j}\in\mathcal{U}:u_{i}>u_{j}}G(s_{j,i})

where G​(⋅)𝐺⋅G(\cdot) is a secure pseudorandom generator (PRG). Assuming no dropouts, the server can compute the aggregation as v=∑ui∈𝒰vi=𝑣subscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝒰subscript𝑣𝑖absentv=\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}v_{i}= ∑ui∈𝒰yisubscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖𝒰subscript𝑦𝑖\sum_{u_{i}\in\mathcal{U}}y_{i}. To enforce the condition C𝐶C of Equation 14, we can simply substitute the PRG G​(⋅)𝐺⋅G(\cdot) with the evaluation of a pseudorandom function (PRF) F​(si,j,Θi(t))𝐹subscript𝑠𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑖F(s_{i,j},\Theta^{(t)}_{i}) where Θi(t)subscriptsuperscriptΘ𝑡𝑖\Theta^{(t)}_{i} are the parameters received by uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} from S𝑆S. It is easy to see that the aggregation remains hidden if two (or more) honest users receive two different parameters. Hence, the server S𝑆S can not execute a model inconsistency attack. We stress that the presented solution (as discussed in (Bonawitz et al., 2017)) is not resilient to dropouts. Still, the same technique  can be applied seamlessly to both SA protocols (of Bonawitz et al. (Bonawitz et al., 2017) and Bell et al. (Bell et al., 2020)) that handle users dropouts. This second approach does not need any additional round of communication. Moreover, unlike the previous approach (i.e., parameter validation using signatures), it preserves the communication complexity of the original SA protocols (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2020) since we do not need to exchange signatures between active users.

Note that SA protocols such as (Bonawitz et al., 2017; Bell et al., 2020) (secure in the malicious setting) already require a PKI. Hence, the proposed solutions (parameter validation using signatures and conditional secure aggregation) can be implemented by using the existing PKI of the SA protocol. Nevertheless, patching model inconsistency becomes consistently harder for variations of the vanilla FL protocol such as Asynchronous Federated Learning (Nguyen et al., 2021; Xu et al., 2021) which is gaining substantial interest thanks to its practical advantages. For instance, in the asynchronous SA protocol proposed in (So et al., 2021a), solving model inconsistency would be a difficult task as aggregating model updates produced by different models is allowed by design. In these directions, solving model inconsistency efficiently remains an open problem.

7.2. Differential privacy and Secure Aggregation

One way to protect against the proposed attacks would be to mix SA with Differential Private-SGD algorithms (Abadi et al., 2016). However, unlike previous solutions (Section 7.1), differential privacy (DP) comes with a high utility cost, especially in the context of FL (Yu et al., 2020). Regardless, standard central-DP approaches (McMahan et al., 2018; Ramaswamy et al., 2020) are ineffective when the parameter server is malicious. Here, the DP-noise is applied only after the model updates have been aggregated by the server. Trivially, if the server is malicious, it can just skip this step and obtain the target’s gradient in clear. Therefore, the proposed attacks remain unaffected. Peculiarly, pure central-DP is the approach used in state-of-the-art implementations (tff, 2021) and employed in real-world deployments of FL (Ramaswamy et al., 2020; McMahan and Abhradeep, 2022). Nonetheless, user-level differential privacy can still be efficiently obtained in the presence of a dishonest parameter server by relying on the distributed-DP model (Kairouz et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022b; Agarwal et al., 2021; Chen et al., 2022a) that combines (partial) local noise application and SA to securely simulate central-DP.131313Note that the server can still exploit the m𝑚m compromised users allowed by the threat model and force them to participate in SA with zero gradient without applying the required noise. In the distributed DP model, this lets the server weaken the privacy guarantee for the target model update proportionally to m𝑚m. More generally, as previous works have exhaustively shown it (Zhu et al., 2019; Fowl et al., 2021; Huang et al., 2021; Boenisch et al., 2021), the application of local noise (i.e., local / distributed-DP) is sufficient to prevent gradient inversion and inference attacks on users’ model updates, and, therefore, the introduced attacks. In Appendix E, we offer a more detailed analysis of the privacy provided by the combination of SA and local-DP against the proposed attacks.

Nevertheless, the combination of SA and DP (Kairouz et al., 2021; Stevens et al., 2022; Chen et al., 2022a, b; Agarwal et al., 2021) is still partially susceptible to model inconsistency attacks since the adversary can isolate the gradient/parameters of the target user in the aggregation. That is, the server can still force the final aggregated value to be a function of the sole target’s training set. Thus, while a suitable amount of local noise still ensures the “privacy by aggregation” property of SA141414To be precise, it implies a consistently stronger form of privacy than “privacy by aggregation” alone as the model update is now also differentially private., the “privacy by shuffling” property remains violated. Indeed, the information leaked from the aggregated model updates can still be traced back to the target—which is known to be the only source of information in the final aggregated value.

8. Conclusion

Our research found that federated learning implementations are susceptible to a critical vulnerability caused by incorrect usage of secure aggregation. As a result, the latter does not provide any additional security to users against a malicious server (even if a trusted PKI is assumed). The primary reason for the security issue is the lack of parameter validation, which would have prevented the server from providing inconsistent views of the global parameters to users.

We emphasize that the proposed attacks are just representative examples of threats induced by model inconsistency, and that other attacks may be devised by exploiting the same general intuition. In order to protect users’ privacy from current and future attacks, we argue that federated learning implementations must account for model inconsistency and prevent it at its source.

Appendix A Alternatives to federated learning

Aono et al. (Aono et al., 2017) leverage a homomorphic encryption scheme to permit users to share encrypted model updates (e.g., gradients) with the server. The latter will compute the new model parameters in an encrypted fashion, using the additive homomorphic properties of the underlying encryption scheme. The new parameters remain encrypted on the server-side.

Truex et al. (Truex et al., 2019) use a similar approach by leveraging the homomorphic properties of Pailler’s cryptosystem. Here, the Pailler encryption scheme is necessary to allow the server to aggregate the model updates in an encrypted form. In contrast to (Aono et al., 2017), the aggregation will be decrypted by the users and made public to the server.

An analogous approach is used by EastFly (Dong et al., 2020) and BatchCrypt (Zhang et al., 2020) with the main difference of keeping the aggregated updates secret to the server: The aggregation is locally decrypted by the users that will also compute the new model parameters (this differs from the original FL protocol (Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; McMahan et al., 2017) in which the parameters are stored and updated by the server). In addition, (Zhang et al., 2020) proposes a batching encoding scheme (that preserves the homomorphic properties of the underlying homomorphic encryption schemes) to reduce the number of encryption operations and speed up the efficiency of the protocol.

HybridAlpha (Xu et al., 2019a) uses a multi-input functional encryption scheme to compute the aggregation. Informally, each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} computes the encryption E​n​cp​ki​(Δ𝒟iΘ)𝐸𝑛subscript𝑐𝑝subscript𝑘𝑖subscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝑖Enc_{pk_{i}}(\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}) of its update Δ𝒟iΘsubscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝑖\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}. Once the server has received all the ciphertexts, it computes the aggregation by decrypting them using the decryption key s​kf𝑠subscript𝑘𝑓sk_{f} for the functionality f​(Δ𝒟1Θ,…,Δ𝒟nΘ)=∑i=1nΔ𝒟iΘ𝑓subscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟1…subscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1subscriptsuperscriptΔΘsubscript𝒟𝑖f(\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{1}},\ldots,\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{n}})=\sum^{n}_{i=1}\Delta^{\Theta}_{\mathcal{D}_{i}}. Analogously, SAFElearn (Fereidooni et al., 2021) leverages either multi-party computation or fully homomorphic encryption to protect the individual’s updates of users.

Poseidon (Sav et al., 2020) significantly deviates from the original FL architecture. In such a system, users are organized according to a tree hierarchy, and a multi-key fully homomorphic encryption scheme is used to protect users’ updates and the parameters of the neural network. At each round of the training phase, the root user sends the encrypted parameters to all users that, in turn, compute their updates according to their local training data. Then, each encrypted user’s update is sent to the parent that will then aggregate all children’s updates. At the end of this recursive process, the root receives the encrypted aggregation (that contains the updates of all users) and will update the parameters. The entire computation of the training process is executed inside the multi-key fully homomorphic encryption scheme. This permits them to keep the updates and the parameters encrypted. The latter remains encrypted even after the training process, and the model evaluation requires further computation inside the multi-key fully homomorphic encryption scheme. Note that Poseidon (Sav et al., 2020) is an extension of SPINDLE (Froelicher et al., 2021). The former handles complex machine learning models (such as neural networks), while the latter supports only generalized linear models.

Lastly, we mention Cerebro (Zheng et al., 2021) that proposes a compiler to automatically transform Python-like domain-specific language into an optimized MPC protocol for collaborative learning allowing users to keep their plaintext data secret. We stress that Cerebro (Zheng et al., 2021) does not relate in any way with FL (Shokri and Shmatikov, 2015; McMahan et al., 2017) and it must be interpreted as an alternative to FL.

Attack applicability

As discussed in Section 4, our attacks are general and equally effective independently from the SA protocol used. This because they exploit a vulnerability of FL caused by the incorrect usage of SA. More precisely, our main attack applies to all the FL/SA protocols that do not prevent the parameter server from deviating from the honest execution. This class also includes most of the schemes that rely on fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) e.g.,  (Fereidooni et al., 2021). The reason is that FHE would still allow the server to multiply the individual encrypted parameters by the constant 00 and produce 00 gradient everywhere when used by the non-target users (see Appendix C). The only requirement is that server is required to collude with a least one user in order to access the result of the attack (the target model update) once decrypted by the pool (e.g., m>0𝑚0m>0).

Protocols based on Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) can stop the server from executing malicious code (Mo et al., 2021; Hashemi et al., 2021). Thus, a properly deployed TEE environment with ideal/perfect hardware and secure and authenticated communication would prevent all the active attacks currently in the literature (Fowl et al., 2021; Lam et al., 2021; Boenisch et al., 2021), including ours. However, the reality is that trusted hardware is vulnerable to side-channel attacks, and there is significant performance degradation when extending side-channel protections to arbitrary computations. Therefore, it remains unclear whether side-channel attacks can be entirely eliminated.

Appendix B Security of secure aggregation

Additional notation

We model cryptographic algorithms (e.g., adversary) as (possibly interactive) Turing machines. If A𝐴A is a deterministic (resp. randomized) algorithm, we write y=A​(x)𝑦𝐴𝑥y=A(x) to denote a run of A𝐴A on input x𝑥x and output y𝑦y; if A𝐴A is randomized, y𝑦y is a random variable. An algorithm A𝐴A is probabilistic polynomial-time (PPT) if A𝐴A is randomized and for any input x∈\bin∗𝑥superscript\binx\in\bin^{*} the computation of A​(x)𝐴𝑥A(x) terminates in a polynomial number of steps (in the input size). We denote by λ∈\NN𝜆\NN\lambda\in\NN the security parameter of cryptographic primitives, and we implicitly assume that every algorithm takes as input the security parameter (written in unary). A function ν:\NN→[0,1]:𝜈→\NN01\nu:\NN\rightarrow[0,1] is called negligible in the security parameter λ𝜆\lambda if it vanishes faster than the inverse of any polynomial in λ𝜆\lambda, i.e. ν​(λ)∈O​(1/p​(λ))𝜈𝜆𝑂1𝑝𝜆\nu(\lambda)\in O(1/p(\lambda)) for all positive polynomials p​(λ)𝑝𝜆p(\lambda). We write \negl\negl\negl to denote an unspecified negligible function in the security parameter. Similarly, we write \poly\poly\poly to denote all possible polynomials p​(λ)𝑝𝜆p(\lambda). Let X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y be two random variables. We say that X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y are computationally indistinguishable, denoted X≈cYsubscript𝑐𝑋𝑌X\approx_{c}Y, if for all PPT distinguishers D𝐷D we have

|\probD(1\secpar,X)=1−\probD(1\secpar,Y)=1|≤\negl.\left|\prob{D(1^{\secpar},X)=1}-\prob{D(1^{\secpar},Y)=1}\right|\leq\negl.

We now describe the ideal and real-world paradigm of MPC (Cramer and Damgård, 2005) that defines the security of MPC protocols (including SA).

Real world

The real world refers to the scenario in which the real protocol π𝜋\pi is executed between the users 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U}. During its execution the parties 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} exchange messages between themself in order to compute the f​(x1,…,xn)=(y1,…,yn)𝑓subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑛f(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{n}). In this setting, we assume the presence of an adversary A𝐴A that can be either semi-honest or malicious. A semi-honest A𝐴A can take control of a subset of users 𝒰~⊂𝒰~𝒰𝒰\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}\subset\mathcal{U}. This will allow A𝐴A to have access to their inputs {xi}ui∈𝒰~subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖~𝒰\{x_{i}\}_{u_{i}\in\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}}, the messages received, and the final output fi​(x1,…,xn)=yisubscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑦𝑖f_{i}(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})=y_{i}. In addition, if A𝐴A is malicious, then it can also program a corrupted user ui∈𝒰~subscript𝑢𝑖~𝒰u_{i}\in\widetilde{\mathcal{U}} to deviate from the original protocol specification (e.g., send malicious messages). We use the notation Viπ​(x∗)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝜋𝑖superscript𝑥V^{\pi}_{i}(x^{*}) to denote the view of the i𝑖i-th party, i.e.,

Viπ​(x∗)=(xi,ri,m1,…,mk)subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝜋𝑖superscript𝑥subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑚1…subscript𝑚𝑘V^{\pi}_{i}(x^{*})=(x_{i},r_{i},m_{1},\ldots,m_{k})

where x∗=(x1,…,xn)superscript𝑥subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x^{*}=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}), risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} are the (private) random coins of uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}, and mjsubscript𝑚𝑗m_{j} is the j𝑗j-th message received by uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i}.

Ideal world

In the ideal world, the protocol execution is replaced by a trusted third party that honestly computes f𝑓f. In more detail, each user uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} sends its input xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} to the third party. The latter computes f​(x1,…,xn)=(y1,…,yn)𝑓subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛subscript𝑦1…subscript𝑦𝑛f(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})=(y_{1},\ldots,y_{n}) and returns yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} to each user xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}. Even in this setting, the (either semi-honest or malicious) adversary A𝐴A can corrupt a set of parties 𝒰~~𝒰\widetilde{\mathcal{U}} and, in turn, obtains their private inputs {xi}ui∈𝒰~subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖~𝒰\{x_{i}\}_{u_{i}\in\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}} and outputs {yi}ui∈𝒰~subscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖~𝒰\{y_{i}\}_{u_{i}\in\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}}.

Security

At a high level, the security of π𝜋\pi is defined by comparing the ideal and real world. In particular, π𝜋\pi is secure if there exists a simulator S𝑆S that simulates the view of a real-world adversary A𝐴A by leveraging the interactions performed in the ideal world. This implies that any attack in the real world “corresponds” to an attack in the ideal world that, in turn, provides the maximum security guarantees that can be achieved. In other words, a secure protocol π𝜋\pi provides at least the same level of security as if we had an honest, trusted party computing f𝑓f without exposing to an adversary the inputs of uncorrupted users.

Definition B.1.

Let π𝜋\pi and 𝒰={u1,…,un}𝒰subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑛\mathcal{U}=\{u_{1},\ldots,u_{n}\} be a n𝑛n-party protocol that correctly computes an n𝑛n-inputs n𝑛n-outputs function f𝑓f and the set of users that participate in the protocol execution, respectively. Let xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} be the input of user ui∈𝒰subscript𝑢𝑖𝒰u_{i}\in\mathcal{U} and let x∗=(x1,…,xn)superscript𝑥subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x^{*}=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}). For 𝒰~={ui1,…,uik}⊂𝒰~𝒰subscript𝑢subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑢subscript𝑖𝑘𝒰\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}=\{u_{i_{1}},\ldots,u_{i_{k}}\}\subset\mathcal{U}, we let V𝒰~π​(x∗)=(𝒰~,Vi1π​(x∗),…,Vikπ​(x∗))subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝜋~𝒰superscript𝑥~𝒰subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝜋subscript𝑖1superscript𝑥…subscriptsuperscript𝑉𝜋subscript𝑖𝑘superscript𝑥V^{\pi}_{\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}}(x^{*})=(\widetilde{\mathcal{U}},V^{\pi}_{i_{1}}(x^{*}),\ldots,V^{\pi}_{i_{k}}(x^{*})) and f𝒰~​(x∗)=(yi1,…,yik)subscript𝑓~𝒰superscript𝑥subscript𝑦subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑦subscript𝑖𝑘f_{\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}}(x^{*})=(y_{i_{1}},\ldots,y_{i_{k}}). We say that π𝜋\pi securely computes f𝑓f if there exists a PPT simulator S𝑆S such that, for every 𝒰~⊂𝒰~𝒰𝒰\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}\subset\mathcal{U}, for every input x∗=(x1,…,xn)superscript𝑥subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛x^{*}=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}), we have:

{S​(𝒰~,x~,f𝒰~​(x∗))}x∗∈\bin∗≈c{V𝒰~π​(x∗)}x∗∈\bin∗subscript𝑐subscript𝑆~𝒰~𝑥subscript𝑓~𝒰superscript𝑥superscript𝑥superscript\binsubscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑉𝜋~𝒰superscript𝑥superscript𝑥superscript\bin\displaystyle\{S(\widetilde{\mathcal{U}},\tilde{x},f_{\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}}(x^{*}))\}_{x^{*}\in\bin^{*}}\approx_{c}\{V^{\pi}_{\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}}(x^{*})\}_{x^{*}\in\bin^{*}}

where x~=(xi1,…,xik)~𝑥subscript𝑥subscript𝑖1…subscript𝑥subscript𝑖𝑘\tilde{x}=(x_{i_{1}},\ldots,x_{i_{k}}) for uij∈𝒰~subscript𝑢subscript𝑖𝑗~𝒰u_{i_{j}}\in\widetilde{\mathcal{U}}.

Appendix C Gradient suppression for arbitrary architectures

In Section 5 we focused on ReLU-based layers as these are instrumental for our second attack (Section 6). Nevertheless, gradient suppression can be achieved for networks composed of arbitrary activation functions at the cost of flexibility and granularity. Intuitively, we can force any differentiable function to unconditionally produce a zero gradient by constraining it to become constant with respect to the differentiated terms. In the context of neural networks, this means making the loss function constant with respect to the trainable parameters of the network. Formally, given a neural network fΘ(t)subscript𝑓superscriptΘ𝑡f_{\Theta^{(t)}} and a loss function ℒℒ\mathcal{L}, this can be achieved by bringing Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)} in a state such that:

(15) ∀x,y,ℒ​(y,fΘ(t+1)​(x))=c,for-all𝑥𝑦ℒ𝑦subscript𝑓superscriptΘ𝑡1𝑥𝑐\forall x,y,\ \mathcal{L}(y,f_{\Theta^{(t+1)}}(x))=c,

where c𝑐c is an arbitrary constant and Θ(t+1)superscriptΘ𝑡1\Theta^{(t+1)} represents any possible alteration of the parameters of the network achievable starting from Θ(t)superscriptΘ𝑡\Theta^{(t)}. Intuitively, when in this state, the parameters of the network have zero gradient since their alteration does not affect the loss function.

Bringing an arbitrary architecture in the state described in Equation 15 is trivial, and, for standard feedforward networks, this requires to act only on the kernels of the last and penultimate layer. Hereafter, we refer to the composition of these last two layers as ϕl​(ϕp​(a⊗θp+bp)⊗θl+bl)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑙tensor-productsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝tensor-product𝑎subscript𝜃𝑝subscript𝑏𝑝subscript𝜃𝑙subscript𝑏𝑙\phi_{l}(\phi_{p}(a\otimes\theta_{p}+b_{p})\otimes\theta_{l}+b_{l}) where ϕlsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑙\phi_{l} and ϕpsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝\phi_{p} are the two arbitrary activation functions for the last and penultimate layer respectively and a𝑎a represents the intermediate state of the network up to the penultimate layer.

To suppress the gradient for most of the network, the kernel of the last layer θlsubscript𝜃𝑙\theta_{l} must be set to [0]delimited-[]0[0]. In this way, all transformations applied to the network’s input by the layers up to the last layer are nullified. Intuitively, this cuts off all parameters of the layers up to the last one from the loss computation, making their derivative 00 for every input. However, in this state, the kernel θlsubscript𝜃𝑙\theta_{l} still receives the gradient since its alteration still affects the network’s output (and so, the loss function.)

Now, to suppress the gradient for the kernel θlsubscript𝜃𝑙\theta_{l} of the last layer, the attacker needs to act on its input; that is, the output of the penultimate layer. In particular, in order to cut off the contribute of the kernel θlsubscript𝜃𝑙\theta_{l} from the loss computation, the attacker needs the output of the penultimate layer to be [0]delimited-[]0[0], i.e., ∀a,ϕp​(a⊗θp+bp)=[0]for-all𝑎subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝tensor-product𝑎subscript𝜃𝑝subscript𝑏𝑝delimited-[]0\forall a,\ \phi_{p}(a\otimes\theta_{p}+b_{p})=[0]. Indeed, given the multiplicative nature of the operation ⊗tensor-product\otimes between the kernel θlsubscript𝜃𝑙\theta_{l} and the ϕp​(a⊗θp+bp)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝tensor-product𝑎subscript𝜃𝑝subscript𝑏𝑝\phi_{p}(a\otimes\theta_{p}+b_{p}), the assignment ϕp​(a⊗θp+bp)=[0]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝tensor-product𝑎subscript𝜃𝑝subscript𝑏𝑝delimited-[]0\phi_{p}(a\otimes\theta_{p}+b_{p})=[0] completely nullifies the contribute of θlsubscript𝜃𝑙\theta_{l} in the layer output, making its derivative zero.

This can be achieved by choosing appropriate values for the θpsubscript𝜃𝑝\theta_{p} and bpsubscript𝑏𝑝b_{p} in the penultimate layer. In particular, the attacker can set θp=[0]subscript𝜃𝑝delimited-[]0\theta_{p}=[0] and play with the bias term bpsubscript𝑏𝑝b_{p} to force the activation ϕpsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝\phi_{p} to output zero. Indeed, when θp=[0]subscript𝜃𝑝delimited-[]0\theta_{p}=[0], we have that ϕp​(x⊗θp+bp)=ϕp​(bp)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝tensor-product𝑥subscript𝜃𝑝subscript𝑏𝑝subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝subscript𝑏𝑝\phi_{p}(x\otimes\theta_{p}+b_{p})=\phi_{p}(b_{p}) and the attacker just needs to set bpsubscript𝑏𝑝b_{p} in such a way that ϕp​(bp)=[0]subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑝subscript𝑏𝑝delimited-[]0\phi_{p}(b_{p})=[0]. This is possible for almost every activation function. In practice, this is even possible for the Sigmoid function that is zero only when its input is −∞-\infty.151515It is sufficient to set bpsubscript𝑏𝑝b_{p} to a large negative number.

After having nullified the contribution of all kernels in the network, the model is now the constant function fΘ​(x)=ϕl​(bl)subscript𝑓Θ𝑥subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑙subscript𝑏𝑙f_{\Theta}(x)=\phi_{l}(b_{l}). Therefore, the bias term blsubscript𝑏𝑙b_{l} (if any) can still receive a non-zero gradient during the application of SGD. Also in this case, the server can either remove the last bias term from the architecture or ignore it during the attack phase (e.g., gradient inversion).

Appendix D Canary-gradient on FedAVG

At least theoretically, extending the canary-gradient attack presented in Section 6 to the FedAVG protocol can be problematic. In FedAVG, a user locally applies multiple iterations of SGD, modifying the parameters of the model. Thus, there is the possibility that the user overwrites the canary functionality during the process. However, this can be easily prevented by the server. Indeed, given the stateless nature of users in FL, the parameter server must distribute the hyper-parameters needed for the training process. In this direction, the server takes care of the learning rate. Therefore, the server can simply select a low learning rate to preserve the canary’s functionality. The rationale here is that the perturbation of the local parameters induced by the local training steps is proportional to the learning rate. A low learning rate ensures to the server a bounded modification of the local parameters and, so, a limited perturbation of the hidden canary functionality originally injected in the model. Instead, the partial dead-kernel in the non-target’s model cannot be revived regardless of the number of iterations and the given learning rate.

In practice, even setting a standard learning rate such as 0.0010.0010.001 (which is quite common, especially towards the end of the training) seems enough to preserve the canary functionality during the local learning iterations. This is shown in Figure 9(a), where the canary functionality is tested after an increasing number of local training steps. We rely on the same setup of Section 6.3.1, and we use a batch size of 646464. As it can be observed, the accuracy of the attack does naturally decrease with the increase in the number of iterations. However, this performance loss is limited, and the accuracy always remains in the 97%percent9797\%-range even in the worst case. Nevertheless, there is a trade-off between effectiveness and stealthiness of the attack, and such a performance loss can be further reduced by considering a lower learning rate. This is shown in Figure 9(b), for a learning rate of 0.00050.00050.0005. In this case, we do not need model inconsistency, and the server can send the same hyper-parameters (learning rate) to all the users in the pool without distinction.

Once computed the output of the secure aggregation, the server can state if the canary has been triggered by cheeking if ξt≠ξt+1subscript𝜉𝑡subscript𝜉𝑡1\xi_{t}\neq\xi_{t+1}. Intuitively, the parameters ξ𝜉\xi are modified if and only if the target user produced a non-zero gradient for ξ𝜉\xi during the training at least once (i.e., the trigger condition has been met).

Appendix E A Note on the combination of SA with Local Differential Privacy as a Defense

When SA is combined with local-DP, the amount of noise applied to the model update recovered by our attacks is proportional to the number of users participating in the round.

In the local-DP setting without SA, the model update of the user u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} accessible by the parameter server is:

Δ^𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)+𝔑ϵ,subscriptsuperscript^ΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝔑italic-ϵ\hat{\Delta}^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}+\mathfrak{N}_{\epsilon},

where 𝔑ϵsubscript𝔑italic-ϵ\mathfrak{N}_{\epsilon} is the local noise applied by u𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝑢𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍u_{\mathsf{trgt}} to make the model updated (ϵ)italic-ϵ(\epsilon)-differentially-private and Δ^𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)subscriptsuperscript^ΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍\hat{\Delta}^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}} is the clipped version of the model update. However, the situation is different when SA is combined with local-DP. In this case, assuming that all the active users 𝒰(t)superscript𝒰𝑡\mathcal{U}^{(t)} apply an equal amount of noise, then the attacks recover a model update defined as:

(16) Δ^𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)+𝔑ϵ+(|𝒰(t)|−1)⋅𝔑ϵ.subscriptsuperscript^ΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍subscript𝔑italic-ϵ⋅superscript𝒰𝑡1subscript𝔑italic-ϵ\hat{\Delta}^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}+\mathfrak{N}_{\epsilon}+(|\mathcal{U}^{(t)}|-1)\cdot\mathfrak{N}_{\epsilon}.

As the target model update inherits the input noise added by non-target users, the amount of noise and, therefore, the degree of protection increases with the number of active users.

In practice, considering DP-SGD based on the Gaussian mechanism (Abadi et al., 2016) and assuming an ideal functionality of SA working on real vectors161616Current SA protocols work in the discrete domain. However, the sum of discrete (independent) Gaussians is not a discrete Gaussian (see (Kairouz et al., 2021) for details)., we can rewrite Equation 16 as:

Δ^𝒟𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍(t)Θ(t)+𝒩​(0,|𝒰(t)|⋅σ(ϵ,δ)2),subscriptsuperscript^ΔsuperscriptΘ𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑡𝗍𝗋𝗀𝗍𝒩0⋅superscript𝒰𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜎2italic-ϵ𝛿\hat{\Delta}^{\Theta^{(t)}}_{\mathcal{D}^{(t)}_{\mathsf{trgt}}}+\mathcal{N}(0,\ |\mathcal{U}^{(t)}|\cdot\sigma^{2}_{(\epsilon,\delta)}),

where σ(ϵ,δ)2subscriptsuperscript𝜎2italic-ϵ𝛿\sigma^{2}_{(\epsilon,\delta)} is the variance of the Gaussian distribution required to achieve (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differential-privacy. Figure 10 shows the “privacy amplification effect” of the combination of SA and local-DP with respect to an increase in active users for three different settings of local-DP: (ϵ=4.58,δ)italic-ϵ4.58𝛿(\epsilon\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu4.58,\delta), (ϵ=2.88,δ)italic-ϵ2.88𝛿(\epsilon\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu2.88,\delta), and (ϵ=1.63,δ)italic-ϵ1.63𝛿(\epsilon\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu1.63,\delta) with δ=5⋅10−5𝛿⋅5105\delta\mkern 1.5mu{=}\mkern 1.5mu5\cdot 10{-5}. The y-axis reports the final privacy budget of the model update recovered by the server after the application of SA. In the plot, we consider FedSGD with a batch size of 646464 and a local training set of 646464 instances per user. Noise multipliers are 1, 1.511.51,\ 1.5, and 2.52.52.5 respectively, with ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-norm-clip of 111. The privacy budget is computed with (Abadi et al., 2016) via its tensorflow-privacy implementation.

To summarize, when local-DP is combined with SA, it is possible to obtain a privacy amplification effect that is proportional to the number of non-target users. Compared to having no SA, users need to add less noise in the local-DP+SA regime to achieve the same level of protection when using a suitable trust-model.171717Other users must be honest and add the expected amount of noise.
